channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Fighting China’s subsidies means copying China’s economic model
item.description: Rather than just raising trade barriers, countries should predict where Chinese subsidies will move next to compete there.

item.title: Trump to cast a shadow over coming Greenland talks
item.description: Officials from the US, Denmark and Greenland are expected to hold talks on Monday and Tuesday – the first since the President mused about taking the territory by force.

item.title: Election Drama Heats Up in Honduras
item.description: The country is the latest target of Trump’s partisan interventions.

item.title: Pete Hegseth’s Bad Week
item.description: The defense secretary is under scrutiny for a series of questionable decisions.

item.title: Modi Walks a Tightrope Between Putin and Trump
item.description: This week’s meeting with Putin will test how well India can balance ties with Russia and the United States.

item.title: Silicon Valley Wants Disaster Bunkers. Norway Wants ‘Preparedness Friends.’
item.description: Norwegians are pioneering better models of catastrophe preparation.

item.title: Africa Was the Biggest Loser of China’s COP30 Triumph
item.description: Decisions about the continent’s future are being made in foreign capitals.

item.title: Why Peace in Ukraine Remains a Distant Prospect
item.description: When two warring parties’ core objectives are fundamentally incompatible, no amount of external pressure or diplomacy can bridge the gap between them. Peace in Ukraine will come eventually, but it almost certainly will not come from US President Donald Trump's current diplomatic push, no matter how many deadlines he sets.

item.title: Eurasia’s Great Water Gamble
item.description: Climate change is rapidly melting the glaciers that feed Central Asia’s rivers, pushing the region toward an ecological tipping point. Against this backdrop, a new initiative aims to revive a long-abandoned plan to redirect part of Siberia’s freshwater to its southern neighbors.

item.title: West Bank Violence Threatens Trump’s Gaza Peace Plan
item.description: Rights groups say the Israeli government is complicit.

item.title: Japan Talks Tough
item.description: Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, was not wrong when she recently said that the country must be prepared to defend itself even beyond its borders. But she would be in a stronger position to strengthen Japan’s military muscle if she were willing to reckon with her political forebears’ war crimes.

item.title: Has the Second World War finally ended for Germany and Japan?
item.description: Doubts about US commitment are pushing Berlin and Tokyo toward military self-reliance they haven’t sought since 1945.

item.title: Trump’s Ukraine Peace Plan Means More War
item.description: After attempting to impose draconian peace terms on Ukraine, the US delegation responsible for negotiating with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who all but dictated those terms, has once again failed to achieve a breakthrough. Even if the Trump administration does manage to get a peace agreement signed, what it contains – and what it omits – is likely to be a formula for renewed conflict.

item.title: The Big Picture
China Intensifies ‘Three Warfares’ Targeting Japan Over Takaichi’s Taiwan Remarks
item.description: Beijing is intensifying its use of public opinion warfare, psychological warfare, and legal warfare against Japan.

item.title: Ecuador’s Warning to Trump
item.description: By rejecting all four ballot measures in a recent referendum, Ecuadorian voters demonstrated an understanding that neither their right-wing president, Daniel Noboa, nor Donald Trump seems to share. Militarizing poor neighborhoods and inviting US troops is no way to resolve a security crisis.

item.title: The U.S. Can’t Talk to Its Neighbors Anymore
item.description: What the postponement of the Summit of the Americas reveals about regional relations.

item.title: US Steps up Defense Cooperation in Southeast Asia
item.description: Washington is making progress with a range of states: from staunch ally the Philippines to newer partner Vietnam and even Cambodia, where China's influence dominates.

item.title: Kyrgyz Election Commission Tosses Results From District With Highest Turnout, Citing Violations
item.description: The commission says all 14 candidates won’t be permitted to run again for the seat, but a court could reverse that decision.

item.title: Is China’s Real Estate Crisis Driving the Next Stage of Homegrown Innovation?
item.description: A closer look at the economic numbers suggests that a bad real estate industry is not all bad news for the Chinese economy.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Grip on the Military Is Getting Stronger, Not Weaker
item.description: Xi continues to eliminate factional networks that could eventually develop into rivals for PLA loyalty.

item.title: The Autocrats’ War on Universities
item.description: It is no accident that aspiring autocrats try to exert control over higher education, given universities' potential to become sites of resistance and promoters of "democratic competence." The real question is why university leaders have not done more to anticipate the far right's latest onslaught.

item.title: China’s New ‘Two-Front Strategy’ Against Japan and Taiwan
item.description: The use of both international lawfare and historical narrative warfare signals a major, under-recognized shift in China’s Taiwan strategy and its approach to Japan.

item.title: Syria’s transition has gone better than expected
item.description: The president has been a deft diplomat, but must do more reassure Syrians

item.title: Kyrgyzstan is losing its status as Central Asia’s only democracy
item.description: The president is muffling the opposition and consolidating power

item.title: Lessons from Japan’s efforts to wean itself off Chinese rare earths
item.description: Numbers one, two and three: it’s a lot harder than it sounds

item.title: South-East Asia and Sri Lanka are reeling from storms and flooding
item.description: Cyclones close to the equator are rare and dangerous

item.title: After a terrible fire in Hong Kong, public fury smoulders
item.description: The government is determined to suppress protest

item.title: The general who refused to crush Tiananmen’s protesters
item.description: A leaked video of his court-martial has suddenly appeared

item.title: Western armed forces have struggled to fill their ranks to deter Russia
item.description: More sensible recruiting policies could help

item.title: What will your child’s Trump Account be worth?
item.description: The president has cribbed a signature policy from an unlikely source

item.title: Some cocaine-smuggling presidents are more innocent than others
item.description: As Donald Trump revives the Monroe Doctrine, he is bewildering America’s neighbours about what it stands for

item.title: A special election puts Democrats on track to flip the House
item.description: Though the predictive power of these contests has shrunk of late

item.title: Republicans still don’t know with Obamacare
item.description: Expiring subsidies are a big political headache

item.title: The weekly cartoon
Politics
Business
Why a small corruption scandal is a big problem for the EU
item.description: Diplomats at the trough in Brussels

item.title: Greece is teaching Germany how to get government online
item.description: A legendary bureaucracy is making Olympian efforts at digitalisation

item.title: The Hague is coping with the decline of international courts
item.description: A loss of prestige for global criminal justice, and for its capital

item.title: Italy’s populist right stalls a sexual-consent law
item.description: Despite harsher penalties for femicide, Italian machismo is not over

item.title: America’s peace initiative has stalled in Moscow
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky faces a political crisis over corruption

item.title: Will the mega-merger wave destroy value for shareholders?
item.description: It’s a coin toss

item.title: How many hours should employees work?
item.description: A question that reveals something about every boss

item.title: To halt their decline, VW and others are turning Chinese
item.description: Foreign carmakers are localising their operations in the country

item.title: Even Europe’s penmakers are under threat
item.description: But one quirky Italian brand is thriving

item.title: China’s unlikely new entertainment capital
item.description: Zhengzhou is emerging as the Hollywood of micro-dramas

item.title: Africa needs to generate more electricity
item.description: It also has to create more demand for it

item.title: Binyamin Netanyahu has asked for a presidential pardon
item.description: Why has he chosen now to do so?

item.title: Russia’s dodgy plan for a pipeline in Congo
item.description: If it is built, it will probably benefit Russia rather than ordinary Congolese

item.title: An insurgency may be brewing against Syria’s new leaders
item.description: Alawites close to the former Assad regime are increasingly unhappy

item.title: Syria uneasily celebrates a year of liberation
item.description: The flaws of Ahmed al-Sharaa’s rule are beginning to show

item.title: China built a swanky cricket pitch to win over tiny Grenada
item.description: The locals love them for it

item.title: Republicans still don’t know what to do with Obamacare
item.description: Expiring subsidies are a big political headache

item.title: Britain’s slot-machine politics
item.description: Voting is becoming a high-stakes, wildly unpredictable gamble

item.title: Hong Kong’s Tragic Fire Shows the Consequences of a Hollowed-out Civil Society
item.description: The colossal failure of regulatory oversight across governmental departments is clear – and Hong Kong has quashed the civilian watchdogs that used to close the gaps.

item.title: Transactional Diplomacy Cannot Bring Peace to Ukraine
item.description: Although diplomacy to end Russia's war in Ukraine is intensifying, the goal cannot be limited to a cessation of hostilities. Unless a negotiated settlement is firmly anchored in existing international law and human-rights frameworks, it will not settle anything.

item.title: How Asia’s Semiconductor Powerhouse Fits into ASEAN’s Strategic Future
item.description: With tensions between Tokyo and Beijing rising, ASEAN and Taiwan must balance economic integration with the political realities imposed by China’s growing assertiveness.

item.title: Timor-Leste’s Digital Statecraft
item.description: How Southeast Asia’s newest ASEAN member built a modern governance model.

item.title: Patrick Drahi has bested his lenders yet again
item.description: The world’s messiest debt restructuring just got even uglier

item.title: How AI is rewiring childhood
item.description: The technology presents dazzling opportunities—and ominous risks

item.title: Saudis Also Fail to Defuse Pakistan-Afghan Taliban Crisis
item.description: Although the first round of talks was not successful, the Saudis will persist in their mediatory effort. Their prestige is on the line.

item.title: At home and at school, artificial intelligence is transforming childhood
item.description: It brings many benefits, but also hidden dangers

item.title: At home and at school, AI is transforming childhood
item.description: It brings many benefits, but also hidden dangers

item.title: Donald Trump looms over Vladimir Putin’s visit to India
item.description: America’s president is helping to make Indo-Russian relations great again

item.title: AI misinformation may have paradoxical consequences
item.description: To understand why, consider the side-blotched lizard

item.title: Can golden toilets fix China’s economy?
item.description: Communist Party officials think so

item.title: Bitcoin has plunged. Strategy Inc is an early victim
item.description: It holds 3% of the world’s total supply

item.title: American sanctions are putting Russia under pressure
item.description: In time, though, its tankers will find new routes

item.title: India’s Special Intensive Revision of Electoral Rolls Is Claiming Lives
item.description: The exercise has rapidly deteriorated into a pressure cooker of impossible deadlines, sleepless nights, and unchecked administrative coercion, now actively claiming lives.

item.title: Trump’s Middle East Order
item.description: The president's transactional style is well suited to the region.

item.title: America’s Magical Thinking About Ukraine
item.description: A bad deal is worse than no deal.

item.title: Vietnam’s Cautious Acceptance of Chinese 5G Technology
item.description: Recent agreements with Huawei and ZTE reflect economic pragmatism rather than a shift in strategic trust.

item.title: Myanmar Opium Cultivation Jumps to Highest Level Since 2015: UN
item.description: The country's conflict is also having a countervailing impact on average poppy yields, which “sharply decreased” in 2025.

item.title: Markets have the money, developing countries need the projects – what’s stopping them?
item.description: Investors assume developing economies are risky, but evidence shows the opposite.

item.title: Thailand Seizes $300M in Assets as Scam Crackdown Deepens
item.description: Bangkok appears determined to clamp down on Cambodia-based scam syndicates, but allegations of high-level Thai involvement continue to dog Prime Minister Anutin.
